animalOfTheDay.name: tiger shark
facts: They are born with distinctive stripes that fade as they mature.
Tiger sharks are one of the few shark species that can tolerate freshwater.
They have unique, saw-like teeth that can cut through turtle shells.
Tiger sharks are called 'garbage cans of the sea' because they'll eat almost anything.

calendar.name: stoat
facts: In cold climates, they turn white in winter and are called ermine.
Stoats are small but fierce predators that can take down prey much larger than themselves.
They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting in trees and water.
Stoats perform a hypnotic 'dance' to confuse prey before attacking.

calendar.name: swordfish
facts: Swordfish have a specialized organ that warms their eyes and brain, improving their vision in cold water.
Swordfish can dive to depths of over 1,800 feet in search of food.
They can swim at speeds up to 60 mph, making them one of the fastest fish.
Their sword-like bill is used to slash at prey, stunning or injuring them.

calendar.name: tamarin
facts: Tamarins have claw-like nails instead of flat nails like other monkeys.
Tamarin monkeys are among the smallest primates, some weighing less than a pound.
They communicate through a variety of high-pitched vocalizations.
They often give birth to twins, which is unusual for primates.

calendar.name: tarsier
facts: They communicate using ultrasonic frequencies beyond human hearing.
Tarsiers are the only entirely carnivorous primates, eating insects, lizards, and small birds.
Tarsiers have the largest eyes relative to body size of any mammal.
They can rotate their heads nearly 180 degrees in each direction.

calendar.name: tasmanian devil
facts: Tasmanian devils are solitary and nocturnal scavengers.
They are known for their ferocious screeches and powerful bite.
They are the largest carnivorous marsupial in the world.
Tasmanian devils are carnivorous marsupials native to Tasmania, Australia.

calendar.name: termite
facts: Termites are more closely related to cockroaches than to ants.
They cultivate fungi in their nests as a food source.
Some termite mounds can be over 30 feet tall and contain millions of individuals.
Termite queens can live up to 50 years, making them among the longest-living insects.

calendar.name: tiger shark
facts: Tiger sharks are called 'garbage cans of the sea' because they'll eat almost anything.
They have unique, saw-like teeth that can cut through turtle shells.
Tiger sharks are one of the few shark species that can tolerate freshwater.
They are born with distinctive stripes that fade as they mature.

randomAnimals.name: parrot
facts: Some species, like the kakapo, are flightless and nocturnal.
They can mimic human speech and sounds, with some learning hundreds of words.
Parrots are among the most intelligent birds, capable of solving puzzles and using tools.
Parrots have zygodactyl feet—two toes forward and two backward—for gripping branches.

randomAnimals.name: marmot
facts: No facts available.

randomAnimals.name: panther
facts: Their dark color comes from a genetic mutation called melanism.
They are powerful swimmers and climbers, capable of dragging prey up trees.
Panthers are not a distinct species but are black-coated leopards or jaguars.
Panthers are solitary and stealthy, hunting primarily at night.
